articles.headline: Despite Warnings, China’s Regulators Failed to Stop Tainted Milk
articles.snippet: The scandal is demonstrating the weaknesses of the Communist Party’s authoritarian political system.
articles.abstract: The scandal is demonstrating the weaknesses of the Communist Party’s authoritarian political system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIJIAZHUANG, China  Barely a month ago, China’s staging of the Beijing Olympics demonstrated how the Communist Party could mobilize its authoritarian political system. But the international scandal now unfolding over China’s contaminated dairy products is demonstrating, again, the weaknesses of that system.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and David Barboza

articles.headline: S.E.C. Concedes Oversight Flaws Fueled Collapse
articles.snippet: The commission’s chairman, a deregulation proponent, ended a voluntary supervision program for Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The commission’s chairman, a deregulation proponent, ended a voluntary supervision program for Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a longtime proponent of deregulation, acknowledged on Friday that failures in a voluntary supervision program for Wall Street’s largest investment banks had contributed to the global financial crisis, and he abruptly shut the program down.

articles.headline: The Financial Adviser as Hand-Holder
articles.snippet: Most of us can take some comfort in the fact that we have time on our sides. Managing our money is a process that unfolds over decades, not days.
articles.abstract: Most of us can take some comfort in the fact that we have time on our sides. Managing our money is a process that unfolds over decades, not days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good financial advisers have the examination skills of an ace psychologist. But some of them actually were psychologists before they switched to helping people manage their money for a living. And as you might imagine, they’ve been awfully busy in recent days.

articles.headline: Markets Can’t Wait for Congress to Act
articles.snippet: The markets may not be as panicked as they were last week, but with every passing day, the situation is getting increasingly dangerous.
articles.abstract: The markets may not be as panicked as they were last week, but with every passing day, the situation is getting increasingly dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here we go again.

articles.headline: Wachovia, Looking for Help, Turns to Citigroup
articles.snippet: Weighed down by mortgage loans, the fourth-largest bank by assets in the U.S. entered into preliminary talks.
articles.abstract: Weighed down by mortgage loans, the fourth-largest bank by assets in the U.S. entered into preliminary talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: As concern spread Friday that more banks might run into trouble even with a $700 billion rescue for the financial system, Wachovia, one of those hardest hit by the housing crisis, became the latest to reach for a lifeline.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Conservatives Viewed Bailout Plan as Last Straw
articles.snippet: After years of acceding to the White House, Republicans in the House found a $700 billion request to be too much.
articles.abstract: After years of acceding to the White House, Republicans in the House found a $700 billion request to be too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The seeds of the House Republican revolt over the financial industry bailout were sown in an e-mail message circulated Monday night as internal animosity built quickly over the Bush administration’s request for $700 billion to prevent an economic collapse.

articles.headline: Retail Firm Forces Chief to Depart
articles.snippet: Jane Elfers, the chief executive of Lord & Taylor who was credited by industry professionals with bringing the sheen back to a down-at-the-heel chain, was forced out in a management shake-up.
articles.abstract: Jane Elfers, the chief executive of Lord & Taylor who was credited by industry professionals with bringing the sheen back to a down-at-the-heel chain, was forced out in a management shake-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jane Elfers, the chief executive of Lord & Taylor who was credited by industry professionals with bringing the sheen back to a down-at-the-heel chain, was forced out in a management shake-up.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Builds Strength With WaMu Deal in Tense Age
articles.snippet: As one institution after another is laid low by the present crisis, James Dimon stands at the head of a small band of bankers who are coming out on top in the new financial landscape.
articles.abstract: As one institution after another is laid low by the present crisis, James Dimon stands at the head of a small band of bankers who are coming out on top in the new financial landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s largest savings and loan teetered on Thursday morning, a senior federal regulator called a familiar number: James Dimon’s.

articles.headline: Beyond Ideology, a Generational Clash
articles.snippet: At times the debate looked almost like an older patriarch and a would-be successor to the family business.
articles.abstract: At times the debate looked almost like an older patriarch and a would-be successor to the family business.
articles.lead_paragraph: One candidate cited Churchill and Eisenhower, and described George Shultz, who served in Ronald Reagan’s cabinet, as a “great secretary of state.”

articles.headline: Rivals Display Stark Contrasts in Clashes on War and Economy
articles.snippet: Barack Obama and John McCain set out sharply different views of how they would manage the country and confront adversaries.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama and John McCain set out sharply different views of how they would manage the country and confront adversaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the economy to foreign affairs to the way they carried themselves on stage, Senators John McCain and Barack Obama offered a dramatic contrast to the nation in their first presidential debate on Friday night, mixing disdain and often caustic remarks as they set out sharply different views of how they would manage the country and confront America’s adversaries abroad.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Breakthrough Reached in Negotiations on Bailout
articles.snippet: Officials said Congressional staff members would work to finalize the language of an agreement and draft a bill to be brought for a vote in the House on Monday.
articles.abstract: Officials said Congressional staff members would work to finalize the language of an agreement and draft a bill to be brought for a vote in the House on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders and the Bush administration reached a tentative agreement early Sunday on what may become the largest financial bailout in American history, authorizing the Treasury to purchase $700 billion in troubled debt from ailing firms in an extraordinary intervention to prevent widespread economic collapse.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Wall Street, R.I.P.: The End of an Era, Even at Goldman
articles.snippet: For most of the financiers who remain, with the exception of a few superstars, the days of easy money and supersized bonuses are behind them.
articles.abstract: For most of the financiers who remain, with the exception of a few superstars, the days of easy money and supersized bonuses are behind them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALL STREET. Two simple words that  like Hollywood and Washington  conjure a world.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Ben White

articles.headline: What’s Free About Free Enterprise?
articles.snippet: Once the federal government declares, “Thou shalt not fail,” there are no limits to how far future risk-takers will go.
articles.abstract: Once the federal government declares, “Thou shalt not fail,” there are no limits to how far future risk-takers will go.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time, in my childhood during the Great Depression, when the streets of Manhattan were filled with unshaven men in threadbare clothes, their coat collars turned up against the cold, their shoes stuffed with newspaper to plug holes in the soles. And there were bank failures.

articles.headline: A Tycoon Tweaks Putin, and Gets Away With It
articles.snippet: Aleksandr Y. Lebedev is an exception to the rule that Russian oligarchs are too frightened to speak out.
articles.abstract: Aleksandr Y. Lebedev is an exception to the rule that Russian oligarchs are too frightened to speak out.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  A certain sense of humor was called for when the billionaire Aleksandr Y. Lebedev looked out at the banquet hall that was glowing with candelabra and bare shoulders, where he had convened Moscow’s elite to raise support for a major new theater project. But he seemed well prepared.

articles.headline: Behind Insurer’s Crisis, Blind Eye to a Web of Risk
articles.snippet: An exploration of A.I.G.’s demise offers insights into the virally connected financial world that is now imploding.
articles.abstract: An exploration of A.I.G.’s demise offers insights into the virally connected financial world that is now imploding.
articles.lead_paragraph: “It is hard for us, without being flippant, to even see a scenario within any kind of realm of reason that would see us losing one dollar in any of those transactions.”

articles.headline: For McCain and Team, a Host of Ties to Gambling
articles.snippet: John McCain, Congress’s most influential member on gambling, has a complicated history with the industry.
articles.abstract: John McCain, Congress’s most influential member on gambling, has a complicated history with the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain was on a roll. In a room reserved for high-stakes gamblers at the Foxwoods Resort Casino in Connecticut, he tossed $100 chips around a hot craps table. When the marathon session ended around 2:30 a.m., the Arizona senator and his entourage emerged with thousands of dollars in winnings.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Don Van Natta Jr

articles.headline: Daring to Say Loans Made No Sense
articles.snippet: A few years ago, Alex Blumberg, a producer at the public radio show “This American Life,” asked: “Why are they lending money to people who can’t afford to pay it back?”
articles.abstract: A few years ago, Alex Blumberg, a producer at the public radio show “This American Life,” asked: “Why are they lending money to people who can’t afford to pay it back?”
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, if you want the real answer, you have to ask a dumb question.

articles.headline: Savings and Loan Crisis May Be Guide for Bank Bailout
articles.snippet: The Resolution Trust Corporation, which helped to sort out the S.&L. debacle, found itself dealing with people trying to game the system to their financial advantage.
articles.abstract: The Resolution Trust Corporation, which helped to sort out the S.&L. debacle, found itself dealing with people trying to game the system to their financial advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Getting Congress to agree on a $700 billion financial bailout package might have seemed difficult, but the really hard work is only about to start.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Are Bracing for Investors to Cash Out
articles.snippet: A spate of hurried sales could unleash a vicious circle within the industry, with the sales leading to more losses, and those losses leading to more withdrawals, and so on.
articles.abstract: A spate of hurried sales could unleash a vicious circle within the industry, with the sales leading to more losses, and those losses leading to more withdrawals, and so on.
articles.lead_paragraph: First, the money rushed into hedge funds. Now, some fear, it could rush out.

articles.headline: A ‘Tabloid Guy’ Calls It a Night After 41 Years With Murdoch
articles.snippet: Longtime New York Post columnist Steve Dunleavy is seeing the curtain come down on his career.
articles.abstract: Longtime New York Post columnist Steve Dunleavy is seeing the curtain come down on his career.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are so many stories about the life and times of Steve Dunleavy, the longtime New York Post columnist and even longer-time Rupert Murdoch acolyte, that some, inevitably, have evolved over the years.

articles.headline: After the Deal, the Focus Will Shift to Regulation
articles.snippet: It is clear that the old system failed, but the diagnosis of why that happened may be crucial in deciding what changes are needed.
articles.abstract: It is clear that the old system failed, but the diagnosis of why that happened may be crucial in deciding what changes are needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before Congress passes a $700 billion bank bailout that nearly all legislators believe to be both necessary and unpopular, the jostling has begun over legislation that may prove to be the first test for the next president: How to reshape the financial system and its regulation.

articles.headline: Wall Street Seeks Signs of Response in Markets
articles.snippet: Even if the frozen credit markets thaw a bit — and many analysts say they will — the days of easy money are over for now.
articles.abstract: Even if the frozen credit markets thaw a bit — and many analysts say they will — the days of easy money are over for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington hopes its sweeping bailout plan will get credit flowing again.

articles.headline: Bailout Plan Is Only One Step on a Long Road
articles.snippet: The next administration will need to shape policy for a nation that will be less accustomed to easy credit.
articles.abstract: The next administration will need to shape policy for a nation that will be less accustomed to easy credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s planned financial bailout is a significant if costly step intended to avert economic calamity, but it may not be the last one, according to economists and finance experts.

articles.headline: Jews and Muslims Share Holy Season in Jerusalem
articles.snippet: A calendar coincidence has led to a kind of monotheistic traffic jam along the paths of the Old City.
articles.abstract: A calendar coincidence has led to a kind of monotheistic traffic jam along the paths of the Old City.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Jews are not quiet in prayer. Even when focused on the most personal of quests, as they are this season  asking God for forgiveness for dark thoughts and unkind deeds in the past year  they take comfort in community, chanting and swaying and dancing in circles, blowing the trumpet-like shofar, a ram’s horn.

articles.headline: To Smother Rebels, Arson Campaign in Chechnya
articles.snippet: At least a dozen homes have been burned to punish families with sons tied to rebels, residents said.
articles.abstract: At least a dozen homes have been burned to punish families with sons tied to rebels, residents said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHALI, Russia  The men who set fire to Valentina Basargina’s house arrived in the stillness of 3 a.m. There were three of them. Each wore a camouflage uniform and carried a rifle. One held a can of gasoline. They wore masks.

articles.headline: Bailout Plan in Hand, House Braces for Tough Vote
articles.snippet: The bill, intended to ease a growing credit crisis, came after a frenzied week of political twists and turns.
articles.abstract: The bill, intended to ease a growing credit crisis, came after a frenzied week of political twists and turns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House braced for a difficult vote set for Monday on a $700 billion rescue of the financial industry after a weekend of tense negotiations produced a plan that Congressional leaders portrayed as greatly strengthened by new taxpayer safeguards.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Treasury Would Emerge With Vast New Power
articles.snippet: Rarely if ever has one man had such broad authority to spend government money as he sees fit.
articles.abstract: Rarely if ever has one man had such broad authority to spend government money as he sees fit.
articles.lead_paragraph: During its weeklong deliberations, Congress made many changes to the Bush administration’s original proposal to bail out the financial industry, but one overarching aspect of the initial plan that remains is the vast discretion it gives to the Treasury secretary.

articles.headline: For Stocks, Worst Single-Day Drop in Two Decades
articles.snippet: Over a trillion dollars vanished from Wall Street on Monday, the blackest day since the 1987 stock market crash.
articles.abstract: Over a trillion dollars vanished from Wall Street on Monday, the blackest day since the 1987 stock market crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the opening bell, Monday looked ugly.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum
